questionList.qu: A compound has a molar mass of `60g/(mol).` If `210g` of this compound is obtained, how many moles were obtained? (do not include units in your answer)
questionList.solution: By using the conversion factor given, we can convert to moles. `210g*(1mol)/(60g)=3.5mol`

questionList.qu: A compound has a molar mass of `15g/(mol).` If `120g` of this compound is obtained, how many moles were obtained? (do not include units in your answer)
questionList.solution: By using the conversion factor given, we can convert to moles. `120g*(1mol)/(15g)=8mol`

questionList.qu: A compound has a molar mass of `36g/(mol).` If `0.5mol` of this compound is obtained, how many grams were obtained? (do not include units in your answer)
questionList.solution: By using the conversion factor given, we can convert to grams. `0.5mol*(36g)/(1mol)=18g`

questionList.qu: A compound has a molar mass of `72g/(mol).` If `0.125mol` of this compound is obtained, how many grams were obtained? (do not include units in your answer)
questionList.solution: By using the conversion factor given, we can convert to grams. `0.125mol*(72g)/(1mol)=9g`

questionList.qu: How many moles are there in 176g of `CO_2`? (do not include units in your answer, round your answer to the nearest whole number)
questionList.solution: First, we need to find the molar mass of `CO_2`, which is around 44g using the periodic table. Then, we can use the conversion factor to convert to moles `176g*(1mol)/(44g)=4mol`
